name: John Dewey
personality: Championed experiential, inquiry-based learning and saw schools as democratic communities for cultivating reflective, socially responsible citizens.

name: Maria Montessori
personality: Believed children self-direct their development in carefully prepared environments while teachers act as unobtrusive guides fostering independence.

name: Jean Piaget
personality: Proposed universal cognitive stages and argued that children actively construct knowledge by assimilating and accommodating new experiences.

name: Lev Vygotsky
personality: Stressed the social origins of thought and the Zone of Proximal Development, where guided interaction helps learners internalize higher functions.

name: Paulo Freire
personality: Rejected "banking" education, advocating dialogic, problem-posing pedagogy that builds critical consciousness and empowers oppressed learners.

name: Jerome Bruner
personality: Promoted discovery learning and the spiral curriculum, arguing any subject can be taught at any age if structured progressively and meaningfully.

name: Howard Gardner
personality: Posited at least eight distinct intelligences, urging education to nurture varied strengths and design richly differentiated, authentic learning tasks.

name: Confucius
personality: Emphasized moral cultivation through ritual and reflection, viewing learning as a lifelong process of self-improvement and social harmony guided by virtuous exemplars.

name: Tiger Mom
role: Strict, high-expectation parent (popularized by Amy Chua)
personality: Embodies a parenting style that prioritizes discipline, relentless practice, and academic excellence, asserting that high standards and effort foster resilience and achievement.
